flags.text: This project guide is not managed by MAKE staff.

guide.introduction: Invented by Cambridge mathematician John Conway, the Game of Life is a cellular automation game that is a zero-player game. The evolution of the cells is determined by the initial conditions of the cells.
guide.introduction_rendered:
Invented by Cambridge mathematician John Conway, the Game of Life is a cellular automation game that is a zero-player game. The evolution of the cells is determined by the initial conditions of the cells.

Relevant parts
  • Game of Life Kit
  • Green 5mm LED
  • Microcontroller (preprogrammed when purchased in a kit)
  • 28-pin socket
  • Ceramic 0.1uF capacitor (104)
  • 100 ohm 1/4W 5% resistor (brown black brown gold)
  • 6mm tactile switch button
  • 2 x AA battery holder
  • Circuit board

parts.text: Microcontroller (preprogrammed when purchased in a kit)

lines.text: Open up the Game of Life bag of components and check to make sure that you have all of the necessary parts to assemble the kit.
lines.text_raw: Open up the Game of Life bag of components and check to make sure that you have all of the necessary parts to assemble the kit.

lines.text: Heat up your soldering iron, wet your sponge, and let's get ready to solder the Game of Life Kit!
lines.text_raw: Heat up your soldering iron, wet your sponge, and let's get ready to solder the Game of Life Kit!

lines.text: You have 16 resistors, all of the same resistance.
lines.text_raw: You have 16 resistors, all of the same resistance.

lines.text: In locations R1 through R16, insert the LEDs into the circuit board. Resistors are not polarized, so it does not matter which direction you put them in.
lines.text_raw: In locations '''R1''' through '''R16''', insert the LEDs into the circuit board.  Resistors are not polarized, so it does not matter which direction you put them in.

lines.text: Solder the resistors in.
lines.text_raw: Solder the resistors in.

lines.text: It is important to clip the leads of the resistors to ensure that there are no shorts in the circuit.
lines.text_raw: It is important to clip the leads of the resistors to ensure that there are no shorts in the circuit.

lines.text: Be sure to save one of these leads, because we will need to use it soon.
lines.text_raw: Be sure to save one of these leads, because we will need to use it soon.

lines.text: Note the notch on the end of the socket.  Match this up with the notch on the silk-screened circuit board.
lines.text_raw: Note the notch on the end of the socket.  Match this up with the notch on the silk-screened circuit board.

lines.text: Insert the socket into its holes and make sure that it is flush with the PCB before soldering it in.
lines.text_raw: Insert the socket into its holes and make sure that it is flush with the PCB before soldering it in.

lines.text: Then carefully solder the socket in, being careful not to bridge any solder pads.
lines.text_raw: Then carefully solder the socket in, being careful not to bridge any solder pads.

lines.text: You have 16 LEDs that you need to solder into the PCB.
lines.text_raw: You have 16 LEDs that you need to solder into the PCB.

lines.text: LEDs are polarized, so it is important that you insert them correctly. The longer lead on the LED is the "+" lead. The shorter lead, also the side with the flat spot on the LED's case, is the "-" lead.
lines.text_raw: LEDs '''are''' polarized, so it is important that you insert them correctly.  The longer lead on the LED is the "+" lead.  The shorter lead, also the side with the flat spot on the LED's case, is the "-" lead.

lines.text: Insert all of the LEDs in, and solder them in.  Once they are all soldered, clip their leads.
lines.text_raw: Insert all of the LEDs in, and solder them in.  Once they are all soldered, clip their leads.

lines.text: In location C3, insert the small yellow ceramic capacitor.
lines.text_raw: In location '''C3''', insert the small yellow ceramic capacitor.

lines.text: This component is not polarized, so it does not matter in which direction you insert it.
lines.text_raw: This component is not polarized, so it does not matter in which direction you insert it.

lines.text: Solder it in and then clip the leads.
lines.text_raw: Solder it in and then clip the leads.

lines.text: Retrieve one of the leads you clipped from your resistors.
lines.text_raw: Retrieve one of the leads you clipped from your resistors.

lines.text: Bend it into a staple shape and thread it through the outer two holes in the location IC2. Refer to the image if you are confused. This is called jumping the chip.
lines.text_raw: Bend it into a staple shape and thread it through the outer two holes in the location '''IC2'''.  Refer to the image if you are confused.  This is called ''jumping'' the chip.

lines.text: Solder it in and then clip the leads.
lines.text_raw: Solder it in and then clip the leads.

lines.text: Make sure that the wire is not in contact with the middle pad.
lines.text_raw: Make sure that the wire is not in contact with the middle pad.

lines.text: In the location marked ON/OFF, press the push-button switch down into the PCB. It should snap into place, and it does not matter in which direction you insert it.
lines.text_raw: In the location marked '''ON/OFF''', press the push-button switch down into the PCB.  It should snap into place, and it does not matter in which direction you insert it.

lines.text: Solder this switch in.
lines.text_raw: Solder this switch in.

lines.text: There is a notch on the chip, so make sure that you match up the notch on the socket with the notch on the chip.
lines.text_raw: There is a notch on the chip, so make sure that you match up the notch on the socket with the notch on the chip.

lines.text: You may need to bend the leads on the chip slightly in order for it to fit into the socket.
lines.text_raw: You may need to bend the leads on the chip slightly in order for it to fit into the socket.

lines.text: Press it into the socket and it should fit securely.
lines.text_raw: Press it into the socket and it should fit securely.

lines.text: If you feel like the battery holder's leads are too long, feel free to shorten them...but not too much.
lines.text_raw: If you feel like the battery holder's leads are too long, feel free to shorten them...but not too much.

lines.text: You will need to tin the leads with solder if you do this, however.
lines.text_raw: You will need to tin the leads with solder if you do this, however.

lines.text: The red wire should go into the hole marked with the "+", while the black wire should be inserted into the hole marked with the "-".
lines.text_raw: The red wire should go into the hole marked with the "+", while the black wire should be inserted into the hole marked with the "-".

lines.text: You can insert the leads from the bottom up if you want the board to look a little cleaner.
lines.text_raw: You can insert the leads from the bottom up if you want the board to look a little cleaner.

lines.text: Insert two AA batteries into the battery holder.
lines.text_raw: Insert two AA batteries into the battery holder.

lines.text: You will see the game start. If you press the ON/OFF button, it will reset into a checkerboard pattern.
lines.text_raw: You will see the game start. If you press the ON/OFF button, it will reset into a checkerboard pattern.

lines.text: Place some sticky tape on the back of the battery holder, and press it on to the back of the PCB.
lines.text_raw: Place some sticky tape on the back of the battery holder, and press it on to the back of the PCB.

lines.text: Now you can keep it on your desk and play the Game of Life!
lines.text_raw: Now you can keep it on your desk and play the Game of Life!
